verses.text: In the tenth year, in the tenth month, on the twelfth day of the month, the word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Ezekiel precisely dates this prophecy, emphasizing its historical reliability. The phrase 'word of the LORD came' establishes divine authority—a concept foundational for understanding prophetic revelation. See also Ezek. 1:1.

verses.text: Son of man, set your face against Pharaoh king of Egypt, and prophesy against him and against all Egypt.
verses.comment: Ezekiel is called to confront Egypt, reminiscent of prophetic confrontations in Exodus 7:1. Egypt represents pride and opposition to God's will.

verses.text: Speak and say, 'Thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am against you, Pharaoh king of Egypt, the great monster lying in the midst of his streams, who says, "My Nile is my own; I made it for myself."'
verses.comment: The Nile symbolized life for Egypt. Pharaoh's claim reflects deep pride and self-deification. God's judgment of 'the great monster' can allude to Leviathan imagery and foreshadow Christ's defeat of pride and evil. See Ps. 74:14.

verses.text: 'I will put hooks in your jaws and make the fish of your streams stick to your scales. I will pull you out of the midst of your streams, with all the fish of your streams that stick to your scales.'
verses.comment: Hooks in the jaws imply total control by God over even the most powerful rulers. This underscores divine sovereignty as seen in Dan. 4:35.

verses.text: 'I will leave you in the wilderness, you and all the fish of your streams. You shall fall on the open field and not be gathered or buried. I have given you for food to the beasts of the earth and the birds of the sky.'
verses.comment: This is an image of utter defeat and disgrace, echoing covenant curses. The lack of burial signifies judgment and separation from God's favor. See Jer. 7:33.

verses.text: 'Then all the inhabitants of Egypt shall know that I am the LORD. Because you have been a staff of reed to the house of Israel,'
verses.comment: Egypt's unreliability is compared to a broken reed, highlighting the futility of trusting in human power over divine guidance. This theme finds fullness in Christ—ultimate trust and mediator. See 1 Tim. 2:5.

verses.text: 'When they grasped you by the hand, you broke and tore all their shoulders. When they leaned on you, you broke and made all their backs unsteady.'
verses.comment: Egypt’s aid failed Israel and brought harm, reflecting a failed promise and misdirected dependence. This anticipates the importance of a trustworthy spiritual authority and a church that does not fail.

verses.text: 'Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I will bring a sword upon you, and will cut off from you both man and animal.'
verses.comment: The sword means divine judgment. God uses historical events for spiritual purposes. Both humans and animals affected show a total judgment, reminiscent of spiritual and physical consequences for turning away from God.

verses.text: 'The land of Egypt shall become a desolation and a waste. Then they shall know that I am the LORD, because you said, "The Nile is mine, and I made it."'
verses.comment: Egypt’s pride is judged. God alone is Creator and Lord, a theme fulfilled Christologically in New Testament references to creation through Christ (Col. 1:16).

verses.text: 'Therefore, I am against you and your streams, and I will make the land of Egypt a ruined desolation, from Migdol to Syene, even as far as the border of Cush.'
verses.comment: 'From Migdol to Syene' marks the whole territory of Egypt, signifying complete judgment—an image of spiritual desolation when separated from God’s covenant and life-giving grace.

verses.text: 'No foot of man shall pass through it, nor foot of beast shall pass through it. It shall remain uninhabited for forty years.'
verses.comment: Forty years symbolizes testing, judgment, and renewal in biblical history (Exod. 16:35). Its frequent appearance anticipates spiritual purification and restoration.

verses.text: 'I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and disperse them through the countries.'
verses.comment: Scattering signifies separation and exile. Yet, it sets the stage for restoration, mirroring the pattern of exile and return for God’s people—a motif fulfilled in spiritual reconciliation through Christ.

verses.text: 'Yet thus says the Lord GOD: At the end of forty years I will gather the Egyptians from the peoples where they were scattered.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy is revealed after judgment. Restoration after exile models ultimate healing and unity in God’s plan, prefiguring Christ’s work of bringing all nations together.

verses.text: 'I will restore the fortunes of Egypt and bring them back to the land of Pathros, to the land of their origin, and there they shall be a lowly kingdom.'
verses.comment: Restoration comes, but as a humble nation. This shows God’s justice and mercy—a balance echoed in Christ’s humility and exaltation (Phil. 2:7-9).

verses.text: 'It shall be the lowest of kingdoms and will never again exalt itself above the nations. I will make them so small that they shall never again rule over the nations.'
verses.comment: Egypt will never again be a dominant power; pride is permanently humbled. God alone raises and lowers kings, pointing to the fullness of divine kingship established through Christ.

verses.text: 'And it shall no longer be the confidence of the house of Israel, bringing to mind their iniquity when they turn to Egypt for help. Then they shall know that I am the Lord GOD.'
verses.comment: Israel’s dependence on Egypt resulted in sin. The lesson is the need for direct reliance on God’s appointed means and authority rather than worldly powers—a principle for spiritual leadership and unity.

verses.text: In the twenty-seventh year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: This date places the prophecy 17 years after the previous one. Demonstrates the continuity of God’s word and faithfulness in fulfilling promises over time.

verses.text: Son of man, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon caused his army to serve greatly against Tyre; every head was made bald and every shoulder rubbed bare, but neither he nor his army received wages from Tyre for the labor they had done against it.
verses.comment: Babylon’s campaign brought no earthly reward, highlighting that God, not man, provides for faithful service. Points to God's ultimate return and reward for perseverance in His work.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: I will give Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. He shall carry off her wealth and take her spoil and seize her plunder; that shall be the wages for his army.
verses.comment: God uses world powers to accomplish His judgment, but the ultimate reward comes from Him. This underlines the principle of providence and divine justice.

verses.text: 'I have given him the land of Egypt as his payment for which he labored, because they worked for me, declares the Lord GOD.'
verses.comment: God positions kings and realms to accomplish His purposes. Babylon received Egypt as divine provision. Affirmation of authority established by God, echoing the biblical stress on legitimate spiritual hierarchy.

verses.text: 'On that day I will cause a horn to spring up for the house of Israel, and I will open your mouth among them. Then they shall know that I am the LORD.'
verses.comment: The 'horn' symbolizes strength and deliverance, a messianic image ultimately fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:69). God empowering Ezekiel to speak prefigures divinely-appointed authority and inspired proclamation for the people.
